title: We are all biased - introduction
description: A brief introduction into how we think and why we do certain things

cover_slide_data.heading: We are all biased
cover_slide_data.intro: and have our crazy points of view

cover_slide_data.heading: We are all biased
cover_slide_data.intro: and have our crazy points of view

published_attributes.title: Welcome
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Hi there,

Welcome to "the bias course." This course is based on the Burning Minds talk that Karolina Roziewicz gave during the 2020 Burning Minds Online Conference titled: "From a smartass to a sage - how the mind, the shortcut and the attitude get your learning into trouble," and its core focus is the influence of biases on our learning.

In this short course you'll learn a bit about the origin of cognitive biases and their impact on (mostly) learning.

What you will find in this short course:

  1. We live in a complex world - why we need mental shortcuts
  2. How mental glitches turn into cognitive biases
  3. Examples of the most common biases
  4. Aaaand... some more biases
  5. How biased are you? - exercise
  6. How biases impede your learning
  7. Overcoming learning biases
  8. Extra - Cognitive bias and entrepreneurship
  9. Extra - Let's play the bias game!
  10. Extra - What's your leading bias? - taka a test
  11. Resources and references

The course is meant to make you aware of your own biases and alert to the way they influence your choices. However, learning to dismiss biases once they occur (you cannot eliminate them but learn to manage them) takes time, practice and tons of humility and self-reflection.

Under each section a comment box is available. Please feel free to share your insights and ideas about what you learn with fellow learners. Some topics might have a dedicated question to answer in the comment section.

The whole course will approximately take 40 minutes, but if you decide to dive deep into the topic of behavioral psychology it might take you years to explore... 🤯

Mind you!

If you are taking this as part of the program with the live session, please make sure you note down your answers to the questions and tasks posted in the course. You will need them for the checkpoint and live session.

Enjoy 🚀.

published_attributes.title: We live in a complex world - why we need mental shortcuts
published_attributes.serialized_body:
VUCA - volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous - have been the buzz word for a few years now. But let's face it - the term is far from being just a passing fad. The world is crazy complex and does its best not to let us forget that.

But hey, we're quite smart creatures and we've found our ways to cope. Let's dive into that and learn how our brain is dealing with the complexity of the world. Press ▶️ below.

published_attributes.title: How mental glitches turn into cognitive biases
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Whether talking about an electric circuit, a computer system or the brain, glitches work in a very similar manner. When you process too much information or processes at once, an error is bound to occur.

Watch this video and learn how the glitches create cognitive biases in turn.

Watch this video and learn how the glitches create cognitive biases in turn.

published_attributes.title: Examples of the most common biases
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Here you'll find some very basic examples of biases we a fall prey to almost every day.

TASK:

Before you watch the video here's a task for you: of the top of your head try listing at least 3-5 misconceptions about the world you have or have had: a situation when you felt that your thinking process was not being really rational but led by beliefs or convictions? Share them in the comments.

Got it? Great. Now watch the video.

published_attributes.title: Aaaand... some more biases
published_attributes.serialized_body:
It might seem unbelievable but some crazy passionate behavioral psychologists a few years back decided to take a look at all the biases out there and took a brave attempt at categorizing and organizing all biases they could find in the literature. This is what they came up with:

Obviously - you don't need to take it word for word. It's here just to exemplify how many areas are influenced by the errors in our thinking.

How are you feeling right now? Scared? Excited? Thrilled? Goooood.

Watch it and share how you did in the comment section.

published_attributes.title: How biases impede your learning
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Did you know that... the biggest obstacle to your learning is your own mind? Obviously, you might get the sense of it by now, but do you know how exactly?

TASK:

Having learned a bit about cognitive biases try to come up with at least 3 ways in which they might impede your learning. Then share it in t comments.

Then watch the video and see if you have come up with similar of the same ones?

published_attributes.title: Overcoming learning biases
published_attributes.serialized_body:
No worries. Although you will always remain biased, you can design your environment to either trigger or eliminate the occurrence of certain biases.

Adam Grant in his newest book "Think Again" (stated in the reference section) talks about constant rethinking of our mental processes, convictions, assumptions and beliefs. You might make it, if you do too.

Take a look at some basic examples on how to overcome the most prevalent learning biases.

Once you've watched the video take a good look back at your practices and share if you've ever used them.

published_attributes.title: Extra - Cognitive bias and entrepreneurship
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Learning is just one of the areas impacted by biases. Though the mechanisms are the same, the implications for your business for example might be catastrophic.

In the video below Peter H. Diamandis talks about a few biases (it's also a great basic bias wrap-up) and points to the influence it might have on the entrepreneurial mindset (watch specifically from 1:25)

Having watched the video, can you also think of other implications that all the biases we have discussed might have on business, perceiving the product and the ability to add business value? Please answer in the comments.

published_attributes.title: Extra - What's your leading bias? - take a test
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Now, here's a simple funny test to help you locate your most prevalent bias. This is meant to only be fun, so please take the results with a pinch of salt.

Do you feel like sharing your results with the rest in the comments? Do you agree? I certainly do with mine 🙈.

published_attributes.title: Extra - Let's play the bias game!
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Virtual is great, but if you ever feel like playing a good old-fashion card game, you might find this pretty interesting. Below you'll find a deck of cards you can download and cut out yourself.

They have been created by Stephanie Walters and Laurence Vagner.

This article also suggests a way to play the cards as "A fun way to explore cognitive biases with your team."

published_attributes.title: Resources and references
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Here are some great resources that will help you explore the topic ob cognitive biases (which is humongous).

If you can recommend any others or you'd like to review and comment on the ones listed below, please do so!

BOOKS:

  • Predictably Irrational Dan Ariely
  • Thinking, Fast and Slow Daniel Kahneman
  • Atomic Habits James Clear
  • Drive Daniel Pink
  • Think Again, Adam Grant

VIDEOs:

(here's a podcast version: )
